docs.snippet: ON Tuesday, when the Academy Award nominations are announced, the people behind ''Stepmom'' will learn if their Oscar strategy paid off: to have Susan Sarandon nominated for best actress and Julia Roberts nominated for best supporting actress. If ...
docs.lead_paragraph: ON Tuesday, when the Academy Award nominations are announced, the people behind ''Stepmom'' will learn if their Oscar strategy paid off: to have Susan Sarandon nominated for best actress and Julia Roberts nominated for best supporting actress. If they succeed, it will be quite a coup. Although there's no reason to question Columbia Pictures when it maintains that Ms. Sarandon has a few more lines, it is, nevertheless, Ms. Roberts who has top billing, the title role and, of course, that smile. Similarly, Billy Bob Thornton may nab a supporting nomination for ''A Simple Plan,'' in which his role as the dimwitted brother is only slightly less pivotal than Bill Paxton's more levelheaded sibling. In fact, Mr. Thornton is pretty much a part of the brothers' simple plan from start to finish. In ''A Civil Action,'' there is no arguing that Robert Duvall plays second fiddle to John Travolta. But in less competitive years, Mr. Duvall's high-powered lawyer might have been a best-actor contender. (Let's not forget that Anthony Hopkins won best actor for 17 minutes of screen time in ''Silence of the Lambs.'') What is going on?
docs.abstract: Michele Willens article on trend toward nominating actors with substantial roles for Academy Awards as supporting actors; move prevents multiple nominees in same film from competing with each other; hard-driving publicity machines also use supporting nominations to telegraph various messages about actor; photos (M)

docs.snippet: David Hare was performing his one-person play, ''Via Dolorosa,'' in London one night last fall when he suddenly became aware of an unsettling noise: a groundswell of coughing coming from somewhere in the audience. It was, it turned out, an ad hoc ...
docs.lead_paragraph: David Hare was performing his one-person play, ''Via Dolorosa,'' in London one night last fall when he suddenly became aware of an unsettling noise: a groundswell of coughing coming from somewhere in the audience. It was, it turned out, an ad hoc protest by a group of ultrareligious Jews upset at some parts of the play, in which Hare uses his recent experiences in Israel and the West Bank as a prism to examine the region's deep conflicts. Even the coincidental presence in the audience of an incensed Harold Pinter, fiercely hissing ''Shut up! Shut up!'' in the dark, didn't put an end to it. The noise increased and rose up at the playwright, all alone on the stage, driving him to the brink of explosion. But he never exploded. ''I wanted to stop and say something, and I know they wanted me to stop,'' he says several months later, safely offstage in his thoroughly comfortable office in Hampstead, one of London's nicest neighborhoods. Handsome and self-assured, he has a deep, rich voice and speaks rapidly but in complete paragraphs that are free of sentence fragments, flabby constructions and inapt words. ''If you say something, you're dead -- you never get the audience back. I've never been more relieved in my life that I didn't do something.''
docs.abstract: Jonathan Van Meter article on the proliferation of one-person shows, most of which appear stuck in the autobiographical mode; photo (L)

Like so many of Oscar Hijuelos's earlier novels, ''Empress of the Splendid Season'' is a chronicle of familial love that unfurls in New York over the last five decades. It is another tale of a Cuban family, torn between fading memories of life back home in Cuba and the glittering promises of the American Dream, between the centripetal powers of kinship and tradition and the centrifugal forces of history and generational change.

docs.lead_paragraph: When I got up last Sunday morning to take a shower at the Trapp Family Lodge in Stowe, Vt., I noticed with some alarm that the water was tepid, at best. I called the front desk to point this out. ''Oh, you're at the far end of the lodge,'' the clerk cheerily responded. ''You need to let the water run for at least 10 minutes. Turn on the tap, too.'' Then she added an important Vermont fact of life: ''It is 15 below outside.''

docs.snippet: Movies by black directors and about black subjects have difficulty surfacing in Hollywood and even in the independent film world, so it's interesting to run into all kinds of them, annotated by the hundreds in ''Facets African-American Films on Vi...
docs.lead_paragraph: Movies by black directors and about black subjects have difficulty surfacing in Hollywood and even in the independent film world, so it's interesting to run into all kinds of them, annotated by the hundreds in ''Facets African-American Films on Video'' from Facets International, the Chicago mail order company. Several hundred titles have been organized into two dozen categories, beginning with feature films. ''Boyz 'n the Hood'' (1991), directed by John Singleton, the first black filmmaker to be nominated for an Oscar (at 23 he was also the youngest), and ''Menace II Society'' (1993), by Allen and Albert Hughes, 21-year-old twins, are representative of the better-known titles among the 150 listed.
docs.abstract: Home Video column on mail-order source for movies by black directors and about black subjects; photo (S)

docs.snippet: How times change. A year ago the latest crop of films aimed at teen-agers focused mostly on ax murders and other staples of the horror genre. That left some of the young viewers and not a few parents squeamish. So this year, the studios are mining...
docs.lead_paragraph: How times change. A year ago the latest crop of films aimed at teen-agers focused mostly on ax murders and other staples of the horror genre. That left some of the young viewers and not a few parents squeamish. So this year, the studios are mining the teen-age market with none of that nasty horror; instead the films are filled with sex. Teen-agers are proving to be one of the most consistent and profitable niches in the movie business. Box office receipts over all are hitting record levels, but with the cost of major pictures soaring, transforming ticket sales into profits has been tough. But this is not so with teen-age films, many of which cost a fraction of a standard studio release: less than $20 million, compared with close to $50 million. In addition, if these films catch on, teen-agers will go to see them two, three or even more times.
docs.abstract: At the Movies column reports that this year's films aimed at lucrative teen-age market involve sex and coming-of-age plots, change from recent crop of ax-murder movies; successful so far are Varsity Blues, and She's All That, starring Rachael Leigh Cook; Sissy Spacek discusses her new films Blast From the Past, Affliction and The Straight Story; photos (S)

docs.snippet: For years, the real source of wealth in the movie business has not been the fees paid to stars, but a portion of the profits on big films that an elite list of actors, directors and producers has been able to command. It is a privilege that has ge...
docs.lead_paragraph: For years, the real source of wealth in the movie business has not been the fees paid to stars, but a portion of the profits on big films that an elite list of actors, directors and producers has been able to command. It is a privilege that has generally been denied one prominent player not on that list, the screenwriter. But a group of top writers broke through that barrier today by announcing that Columbia Pictures has agreed to share a portion of the profits of successful movies with them in addition to paying their usual fees.
docs.abstract: Columbia Pictures agrees to share portion of profits of successful movies with screenwriters, contractual term formerly commanded only by elite list of actors, directors and producers; deal, announced by group of top writers, is combination of symbol and substance, because it is not clear how enforceable it is; it is likely to place heavy pressure on other studios to match these terms and shift slightly balance of power in movie business toward writers; it addresses what has been growing source of bitterness for screenwriters; although agreement is negotiated by small group of highly successful writers, it covers any writer who meets certain fixed criteria; it would cover hundreds of writers in Hollywood (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: BY the time Super Bowl XXXIII gasped to an end on Sunday night, there could not be a soul left in this city to doubt the dominance of sports in our social, political and, yes, moral universe. Let's not even discuss the XI hours of Sunday football programming on Fox television or the numbing M's of words inspired by this rather dull game. New York, which likes to think of itself as impervious to any outside force short of a nuclear attack, was transformed on Super Sunday. Streets were fairly empty, restaurants uncrowded and theater lines short -- all because gargantuan men from Denver and Atlanta were smashing into one another on the tube.
docs.abstract: Clyde Haberman column on Super Bowl Sunday in New York City discusses impact of sports on city (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The fate of ''At First Sight,'' the Irwin Winkler film that opened to tepid reviews a few weeks ago, probably won't depend on the publishing and real estate magnate Mort Zuckerman's seconds-long performance as a surly, tattered homeless man. But Mr. Zuckerman's screen debut is a reminder that it may be time to update Andy Warhol's dictum about everyone's getting 15 minutes of fame. Now almost everyone seems to get at least five seconds of it on screen.
